channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Attackers in Pakistan Kill Anti-Polio Workers
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility in the killings of six health workers on Tuesday, but Taliban insurgents have vowed to target them.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A Pakistani mother mourned her daughter, who was killed on Tuesday in an attack on health workers participating in a drive to eradicate polio from Pakistan.

item.title: Mathieu Ngudjolo, Congolese Warlord, Is Acquitted of War Crimes
item.description: Testimony was “too contradictory and too hazy” to convict Mathieu Ngudjolo of a 2003 attack on a village that left 200 dead, the International Criminal Court said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: The Lede Blog: Controversial Israeli Embassy Facebook Page Taken Down 'for Maintenance'
item.description: The Israeli embassy in Ireland has temporarily removed its entire Facebook page from the Web, but taken to Twitter to continue arguing with critics over a Christmas message,
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a Christmas card sold by pro-Palestinian activists in Ireland.

item.title: Richard Engel of NBC Is Freed in Syria
item.description: Richard Engel, the chief foreign correspondent for NBC News, and three of his crew members were freed after five days in captivity.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN STELTER and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:credit: Anadolu via AP TV, via Associated Press
item.media:description: NBC chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel, right, crossed back into Turkey Tuesday after he and his crew were freed unharmed following five days of captivity inside Syria.

item.title: How Wal-Mart Used Payoffs to Get Its Way in Mexico
item.description: Wal-Mart de Mexico was an aggressive and creative corrupter, offering large payoffs to get what the law otherwise prohibited, an examination by The New York Times found.
item.category: Wal-Mart de Mexico SAB de CV
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARSTOW and ALEJANDRA XANIC von BERTRAB

item.title: Iraq’s President Hospitalized With ‘Medical Emergency’
item.description: Iraq’s president, Jalal Talabani, was taken to a hospital in Baghdad after suffering a medical emergency on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:credit: Scott Nelson/WpN for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jilal Talabani of Iraq, pictured in May 2006, has been receiving medical treatment abroad in recent years.

item.title: Bangladesh Finds Gross Negligence in Factory Fire
item.description: A government inquiry says criminal charges should be brought against the owner of the Tazreen Fashions factory, where a Nov. 24 fire killed 112 people.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Khaled Hasan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Tazreen Fashions factory after the fire.

item.title: E1 on West Bank is Empty but Full of Meaning
item.description: A battle over E1, a largely empty patch of the West Bank, speaks to the seemingly insurmountable differences between the Israelis and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khaled al-Saidi, right, said his family bought land in E1, between East Jerusalem and Maale Adumim, in the 1990s. The Israelis have told him to leave.

item.title: Sasol Betting Big on Gas-to-Liquid Plant in U.S.
item.description: Sasol, a South African company, plans to take advantage of a glut of cheap gas to make diesel and other refined products at competitive prices in Louisiana.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN M. BRODER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: The Oryx natural gas processing plant in Qatar, where Sasol is converting natural gas to diesel fuel.

item.title: Russia Sends Warships Toward Syria for Possible Evacuation
item.description: The move elooked like preparation for a potential evacuation of Russian citizens, who are scattered across Syria as a result of intermarriage and longstanding economic ties.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Ancient Bones That Tell a Story of Compassion
item.description: In Vietnam, archaeologists say, a Stone Age community took care of a man who couldn’t take care of himself.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GORMAN
item.media:description: Almost all the other skeletons at the Man Bac site, south of Hanoi, are straight. But the man now called Burial 9 was laid to rest curled in a fetal position that suggests lifelong paralysis.

item.title: African National Congress Chooses Business Tycoon as Deputy President
item.description: Cyril Ramaphosa has become the heir apparent to the top job and South Africa’s presidency once the nation’s leader, Jacob Zuma, ultimately leaves office.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa, a union leader turned business tycoon, celebrated his election as deputy president of the African National Congress party Tuesday.

item.title: Poland Finds It’s Not Immune to Euro Crisis
item.description: Even with the healthiest big economy in Europe, Poland cannot escape the Continent’s economic downturn.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: The assembly line at Fiat's Tychy factory in Poland, shown in 2009. Fiat recently announced layoffs at the factory.

item.title: Gay Man’s 3-Year Sentence Is Upheld by Cameroon Court
item.description: Activists said the ruling was another setback for gay men and lesbians in the country, widely viewed as the most repressive in Africa when it comes to prosecuting same-sex couples.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hearing Into Litvinenko’s Death Still Leaves Motive a Mystery
item.description: A hearing last week into the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer, only added to speculation about why he was poisoned in a London bar.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Alexander V. Litvinenko in 2004; he died two years later.

item.title: Japan’s Next Leader, Shinzo Abe, Shifts Focus
item.description: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s presumptive new prime minister, whose earlier term ended in failure in 2007, is in many ways a changed man, shifting his focus from nationalism to the economy.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, set to be prime minister, said Monday that there would be no negotiation over Japan’s stake in islands that China also claims, but his position is no tougher than the incumbents’.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Optimistic About Relationship With China
item.description: Gary F. Locke, the United States ambassador to China, spoke at a sold-out forum in which he said both countries had become inextricably linked to each other economically.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Casey Kelbaugh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ambassador Gary F. Locke of the United States said the relationship with China was bound to grow.

item.title: World Briefing | Mideast: Chief Public Prosecutor in Egypt Quits After One Month
item.description: The chief public prosecutor appointed last month by President Mohamed Morsi stepped down Monday after a demonstration by district prosecutors accusing him of political bias.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: World Briefing | Mideast: 30 Die in Bombings and Gunfire in Several Iraqi Cities
item.description: A wave of attacks across Iraq on Monday killed at least 30 people and wounded dozens more.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico’s New Leader Outlines Shift in Antidrug Policy
item.description: President Enrique Peña Nieto promised on Monday to modify the strategy, spearheaded by his predecessor, Felipe Calderón, of unleashing the military on narcotics organizations.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: World Briefing | Science and Health: Lack of Funds Could Weaken Malaria Fight, Report Says
item.description: The world has made great progress against malaria, but the fight is stalling for lack of funds, the World Health Organization’s annual report on malaria concluded on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Observatory: Fossils of New Species Discovered in England
item.description: A tiny, fossilized crustacean that lived 425 million years ago has been discovered, remarkably intact, in a rock formation in Herefordshire, England.
item.dc:creator: By SINDYA N. BHANOO
item.media:description: A view of Pauline avibella, a shrmplike marine creature, from a computer-generated model.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Multinational Military Force Expected for Mali
item.description: France expects that the United Nations Security Council will authorize the deployment of a multinational African military force to regain control of the country’s north.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Report Cites Bias by Police In Killings In Canada
item.description: A pig farmer managed to murder 49 women before his arrest in 2002 largely because of “systemic bias by the police” against the victims, many of whom were from aboriginal groups, an inquiry has found.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Lashkar Gah Journal: A Pristine Afghan Prison Faces a Murky Future
item.description: There is no doubt that Helmand Central Prison in Afghanistan is impressive, but the only question is how long it will stay that way once Western forces leave and Western money dwindles.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inmates at the Helmand Central Prison in Lashkar Gah, Afghanistan, in an outdoor area.
